## TypeScript Template with Clean Architecture and Design Patterns

### Introduction

This TypeScript template is designed to follow the principles of Clean Architecture, adopting Domain-Driven Design (DDD) principles, and incorporating the Singleton, Repository, and Factory design patterns. The combination of these practices provides a modular, maintainable, and scalable structure for application development.

### Design Patterns

#### 1. Singleton Pattern
![](data:image/png;base64,)

The Singleton pattern ensures that a class has only one instance and provides a global point of access to that instance. This is particularly useful for managing shared resources and ensuring a single source of truth for certain components.

**References:**
- [Singleton Pattern](https://refactoring.guru/design-patterns/singleton)

#### 2. Repository Pattern
![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1128/1*VdeHRnrn3us9WguuvneLDQ.png)

The Repository pattern focuses on separating data access logic from business logic. It provides an interface for accessing data stored in a data source, allowing abstraction and facilitating the interchangeability of storage implementations.

**References:**
- [Repository Pattern](https://refactoring.guru/design-patterns/repository)

#### 3. Factory Pattern
![](https://unity.com/sites/default/files/styles/810_scale_width/public/2023-04/Copy%20of%203-1%20FactoryDiagram.jpeg?itok=CNN1TqO2)

The Factory pattern is used to create objects according to a common interface. This promotes consistent object creation and provides flexibility by allowing the creation of concrete objects without specifying their exact class.

**References:**
- [Factory Pattern](https://refactoring.guru/design-patterns/factory-method)

### SOLID Principles
![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1400/1*XOMTPWTpDLypkp079p9XXg.png)

#### 1. Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)

Each class should have only one reason to change, i.e., a single responsibility. This promotes cohesion and facilitates maintenance.

**References:**
- [Single Responsibility Principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single_responsibility_principle)

#### 2. Open/Closed Principle (OCP)

Classes should be open for extension but closed for modification. This is achieved by adding new features without changing existing code.

**References:**
- [Open/Closed Principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open/closed_principle)

#### 3. Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP)

Instances of a base class should be replaceable by instances of its derived classes without affecting the correctness of the program.

**References:**
- [Liskov Substitution Principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liskov_substitution_principle)

#### 4. Interface Segregation Principle (ISP)

It is preferable to have many specific interfaces than a general interface. This prevents classes from implementing methods they do not use.

**References:**
- [Interface Segregation Principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interface_segregation_principle)

#### 5. Dependency Inversion Principle (DIP)

High-level modules should not depend on low-level modules. Both should depend on abstractions. Additionally, abstractions should not depend on details, but details should depend on abstractions.

**References:**
- [Dependency Inversion Principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependency_inversion_principle)

### Domain-Driven Design (DDD)

Clean Architecture with DDD aims to organize code into meaningful layers, such as the Domain layer, Application layer, Infrastructure layer, etc. Each layer serves a specific purpose and communicates with adjacent layers in a controlled manner.

**References:**
- [Domain-Driven Design](https://www.domainlanguage.com/ddd/)

### Folder Structure

```plaintext
src/
|-- app/
|   |-- config/
|   |-- controllers/
|   |-- dependency-inyections/
|   |-- middleware/
|   |-- routes/
|   |-- server/
|
|-- features/
|   |-- context/
|       |-- application/
|       |-- domain/
|       |-- infrastructure/
|
|-- shared/
|   |-- domain/
|   |-- infrastructure/
|       |-- client/
|       |-- constants/
|       |-- dependency/
|       |-- implementation/
|       |-- interfaces/
|       |-- persistance/
|       |-- stream/
```
